Title.evidence: Ultrasonic Pupillometry for Nociception Monitoring: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: randomised into three groups: group P (saline), group S1 (0.2 μg/kg sufentanil), and group S2 (0.4 μg/kg sufentanil). Randomisation was computer-generated with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Participants.evidence: Ninety-three patients, aged 18-65 years, with ASA physical status I or II, scheduled for elective surgery under general anesthesia at the Second Affiliated Hospital of Soochow University

Intervention.evidence: randomised into three groups: group P (saline), group S1 (0.2 μg/kg sufentanil), and group S2 (0.4 μg/kg sufentanil).

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial aimed to evaluate the correlation between ultrasonic pupillary dilation reflex (PDR) and sufentanil dose during anesthesia induction.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was PDR amplitude and rate, measured at four time points (T0-T3) using ultrasound.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was maintained for anesthesiologists and outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Ninety-three patients, aged 18-65 years, with ASA physical status I or II, scheduled for elective surgery under general anesthesia at the Second Affiliated Hospital of Soochow University, were enrolled from March 2021 to October 2023.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Of the 93 randomised, 89 were analysed (group P: 30, group S1: 31, group S2: 28).

Result_Outcome.evidence: PDR amplitude and rate were negatively correlated with sufentanil dose [Spearman r = −0.84, 95% CI −0.88 to −0.77, p < 0.01; Spearman r = −0.74, 95% CI −0.82 to −0.64, p < 0.01].
